text:
Twelve days, sixteen 
manufacturing sites.

Clean rooms, hard hats, and 2000
degree incinerators.

We came to Denmark and the 
Netherlands in the dead of 
winter
certainly not for a vacation,

but to learn what best-in-class 
companies

are doing to transform
their operations for a low-
carbon future.

We were impressed by the huge 
potential of offshore wind

as a clean energy source for the
future not only in Denmark but 
across the globe.

We learned to appreciate the 
enormous complexity of 
offshore wind

but we also identified three key
enablers for scaling

that Denmark's Port Esbjerg has 
put into practice.

The first is flexibility for 
electricity offtake.

Offshore wind power fluctuates 
with the weather,
not with consumer demand.

Having multiple means of using 
this electricity,

such as using it to produce 
green hydrogen,

helps absorb excess power and 
put it to use.

The second is collaboration 
among players in the energy 
supply chain.

Port Esbjerg is a hub for 
collaboration,

hosting key players at their 
facilities,

As well as gathering industrial 
expertise,

and accelerating the sharing of 
innovative insights
across these different companies

The third and final one is 
regulatory support.

Our hosts at Port Esbjerg work 
closely

with Danish and European 
government institutions

to stay on top of the latest 
demands

for offshore wind and to also 
promote the rapid deployment of 
new projects.

We had a chance to visit Amager 
Bakke

Which is a waste incinerator 
based in Denmark - Copenhagen,

The plant was built in 2016 by 
Amager Resource Center

that is owned by the five 
municipalities that the 
incinerator serves.

It replaced an outdated 
incinerator

and was designed to be more 
energy efficient,

and to improve the recovery of 
specific commodities such as 
metals from waste.

A key feature is its ability to 
generate both heat and 
electricity,

and switch between the two 
outputs based on current demand.

Copenhagen is uniquely 
positioned

to take advantage of the heat 
generation capability

as the whole city relies on 
district heating

where hot water and steam is 
generated centrally and then fed
to buildings

through an underground pipeline 
network.

Being directly connected to the 
district heating system

also enables the Amager Bakke 
waste-to-energy plant to include

design features that boost the 
energy efficiency of the 
incinerator.

The plant is a prominent city 
landmark,

only a 10-minute drive from the 
city center,

but it was hard to tell that we 
were in an active waste 
incinerator.

Not only was it built with a 
sloped roof

covered with an all-weather ski 
slope,

but its vacuum system was very 
effective in managing odors.

Standing only 50 feet away from 
a bunker

filled with 12 tons of waste, we
could hardly smell anything.

The Netherlands' unique 
positioning

as an international leader in 
agriculture

stems from its culture of 
collaboration

and continuous improvement of 
production methods.

Among the most important 
innovations

are high-yield and 
technologically advanced 
greenhouses

that use precision agriculture 
to optimize production.

Precision farming is extremely 
effective

for gaining a high yield from 
scarce resources

and developing agriculture that 
is resilient

against climate change while 
reducing the environmental load.

We visited Koppert Cress, a 
producer of microgreens

who sells to some of the top 
restaurants around the world.

We were lucky enough to not only
tour the greenhouses,
but also taste the microgreens.

Koppert Cress has five 
greenhouses

containing eight different 
climactic zones,

which enable it to grow 
microgreens from around the 
world in controlled conditions.

Using a circular system to 
capture and store heat 
underground,

Koppert Cress is reducing its 
reliance on external energy 
sources.

The microgreens themselves are 
remarkably varied and packed 
with flavor.

Turns out Rock Chives taste like
garlic,
Chilli Cresses like mustard
and Borage Cresses like oysters.

Sechuan buttons set your mouth 
tingling,

and BlinQ blossoms undo the 
effect.
It's easy to imagine

how they might be used in fine 
dining

to dazzle and delight the 
palate.

We designed this course to give 
our students a glimpse

into the future of 
decarbonization

What it might look like in 
energy, transportation, and 
production processes.

We took 43 students to Denmark 
and The Netherlands

Two countries leading the way in
the energy transition
and sustainable production
A major purpose of the course

is to bring students to go and 
see

many of these decarbonization 
activities in progress

There's great value in actually 
seeing these projects with our 
own eyes.

Going and talking to the people 
who have been working on them,

understanding the challenges 
they faced,

but ultimately seeing what's 
possible.

When our students finish their 
time at HBS
we want to have inspired them
with all the opportunities and

and what is possible in the 
energy transition
that lies ahead of us all.
